title.value: Vulnerability of terrestrial vertebrate food webs to anthropogenic threats in Europe
title.justification: The title reflects the main focus of the paper on assessing the vulnerability of food webs involving terrestrial vertebrates to human-induced threats in Europe.
title.quote: Vulnerability of terrestrial vertebrate food webs to anthropogenic threats in Europe

extractions.description: The research investigates the indirect consequences of anthropogenic threats on biodiversity, specifically focusing on European vertebrate food webs. It integrates data on trophic interactions among over 800 terrestrial vertebrates and their associated human-induced threats, quantifying and mapping the vulnerability of various food web components to six major threats: pollution, agricultural intensification, climate change, direct exploitation, urbanization, and invasive alien species and diseases.

type.justification: The study empirically investigates the impact of anthropogenic threats on food webs using data on over 800 terrestrial vertebrates, examining interactions and modeling their vulnerability to various threats, thus demonstrating an empirical approach.
type.quote: In this study, we investigate the indirect consequences of anthropogenic threats on biodiversity in the context of European vertebrate food webs.

name.justification: The study focuses on the ecological impacts of anthropogenic threats on food webs, a topic within the field of Ecology, specifically addressing species interactions and ecosystem functioning.
name.quote: By integrating network ecology with threat impact assessments, our study contributes to a better understanding of the magnitude of anthropogenic impacts on biodiversity.

name.justification: The paper addresses the impact of various threats on biodiversity, a core concern in Conservation Biology, and provides insights useful for conservation efforts.
name.quote: Our findings suggest that species interactions can improve our understanding of the far-reaching impact of threats on biodiversity.

name.justification: The study examines species interactions within trophic networks and their vulnerability to threats, making it relevant to Trophic Ecology.
name.quote: We integrated data on trophic interactions among over 800 terrestrial vertebrates, along with their associated human-induced threats.

name.justification: The dataset is used in the paper to describe the types of threats each species is vulnerable to within their range.
name.quote: We used the European Red List of species (EEA, 2018), which describes the types of threats that each species is known to be vulnerable to, anywhere within their range.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is referenced as the 'European Red List of species' by the European Environment Agency (2018), reflecting the source and context of its usage.
referenced_paper_title.quote: European Environment Agency. (2018). European red lists of species.

name.justification: The dataset is used in the research for trophic interactions among European vertebrates, providing the structural basis for the analysis.
name.quote: We used an updated version of the Tetra-­EU metaweb of the trophic interactions between all vertebrate species in Europe (Maiorano et al., 2020).

referenced_paper_title.value: TETRA-EU 1.0: A species-level trophic metaweb of European tetrapods
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Tetra-EU metaweb is referenced in the paper by Maiorano et al. (2020), explicitly connecting the dataset to this foundational research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Maiorano, L., Montemaggiori, A., Ficetola, G. F., O'Connor, L. M. J., & Thuiller, W. (2020). TETRA-­EU 1.0: A species-­level trophic metaweb of European tetrapods.
